thread.title: MACC men, women have preseason scrimmages set
thread.title_full: MACC men, women have preseason scrimmages set

author: Chuck Embree
title: MACC men, women have preseason scrimmages set
text: MACC men, women have preseason scrimmages set Comment Posted Oct. 6, 2015 at 12:45 PM By Chuck Embree Posted Oct. 6, 2015 at 12:45 PM Moberly The official start of basketball practice for teams within the National Junior College Athletic Association began Oct. 1 and that includes the Greyhound men and women’s teams at Moberly Area Community College. Teams are allowed to schedule up to four presason scrimmage dates prior to the tip-off of the start of the 2015-16 season when games can officially begin the Halloween Eve weekend. MACC women is coming off a season that was riddled with player injuries, mostly having just six players available during the second semester, where they finished at 13-19 overall and went 4-6 in NJCAA Region 16 under coach Chad Killinger. Thirteen of his 14 players on the roster are freshmen. Returnee Daria Ivanova (5’5) of Kursk, Russia, is the only sophomore. The Greyhound men’s team posted an overall record of 22-10 and a 4-4 finish in Region 16 play, including a second place finish in the regional tournament championships for the fourth straight year. The MACC women’s team participates in three jamboree sessions playing two to three scrimmages at each venue. On Oct. 10 they are at IllinoisCentral College of Peoria, Ill, Oct. 18 MACC travels to Southwest Illinois College at Belleville, Ill., and Oct. 23 has Moberly at Johnson CountyCC of Overland Park, Kansas. The Greyhound women are at home Oct. 26 to scrimmage Stephens College of Columbia. MACC men will participate at a jamboree hosted at Central Missouri State University of Warrensburg, and Oct. 24 at John Wood College of Quincy, Ill. The Greyhounds will host scrimmages against Columbia College on Oct. 21, and an exhibition against Pure PrepAcademy on Nov. 2. The scrimmage against Columbia College will ask patrons to bring a bottle of Gatorade or similar sports enhancement drink and donate it to the program. Preseason scrimmages are open to the public. By Chuck Embree
